config.title: Long-term conditions assessment
config.intro_copy:
This self-assessment will help you to find out if you are receiving the right kind of care and support for your situation.

At the end it will provide you with a printable checklist, plus advice on what further help you may be entitled to.
config.intro_copy_alt:
This self-assessment will help you to find out if you are receiving the right kind of care and support for your situation.

At the end it will provide you with a printable checklist, plus advice on what further help you may be entitled to.

q.title: New question
q.body: How well do you understand your health condition?

a.body: I'm not confident that I understand my condition
I know a bit about my condition but would like to know more
I think I understand my condition well

q.title: New question
q.body: Do you know what having a long-term condition means?

a.body: No, I don't know what this means
Yes, I have a good understanding of what this means

q.title: New question
q.body: How do you feel about your medication?

a.body: I wish I didn't take as many medicines as I do
The medicines I take have significant side effects
I have no problems with the medicines I take

q.title: New question
q.body: Have you agreed a care plan with your GP, nurse or care worker?

a.body: No
Yes, but I don't feel my care plan is working for me
Yes, I'm happy with my care plan and the care I receive

q.title: New question
q.body: Do you know where to go for the information you need, such as finding out about how to manage your condition or what treatments might be right for you?

a.body: No, I'm not sure where to start
Yes, I know where to go for the information I need
I do know where to go for some things, but not everything

q.title: New question
q.body: Have you been offered training in managing and living with your condition?

a.body: No, I haven't been offered training
Yes, I have been for free NHS training
Yes, but I don't think that training is for me

q.title: New question
q.body: Have you been offered any equipment or aids to help you manage at home?

a.body: No, I don't have any aids or equipment at home
Yes, I already have some equipment to help me look after myself or my condition
Yes, I've had a home assessment

q.title: New question
q.body: Do you know about any local or national patient groups where you can share experiences and tips?

a.body: No, I'm not aware of any local or national groups for people like me
I'd like to meet other people like me but I don't know where to start
Yes, I am in touch with a local patient support group

q.title: New question
q.body: Are you struggling to make lifestyle changes like losing weight or stopping smoking?

a.body: I don't think changing my lifestyle would make much difference to my health
I want to change my lifestyle, as I know it would help my condition but I'm finding it difficult
I've already made changes in my life, such as stopping smoking, and feel much better for it

results.ri: Based on your responses you could:

links.li: Here are some links that you may find useful:

result_items.ri: Ask your GP, nurse or care worker for more info on your condition
See your GP to review your medicines
See your pharmacist or GP about the medicines you take
Talk to your GP, nurse or care worker about care plans
Review your care plan with your GP, nurse or care worker
Consider being an expert patient or trainer
Speak to your GP, nurse or care worker about training
Ask your GP, nurse or care worker about equipment that could help
Arrange a home assessment through your GP, nurse or care worker
Ask your GP for details about patient groups
Ask your GP for details about patient groups
Ask your GP about lifestyle changes that could help

link_items.ri: Training and the expert patient programme

ib.title: What is a long-term condition?
ib.body: A long-term condition is one that can be treated and managed but not cured, so you are likely to have it for many years, even the rest of your life.
ib.name: What is a long-term condition?

ib.title: What a ‘care plan' is
ib.body: Everybody with a long-term condition can have a written care plan, agreed with their health or social care worker, to help manage their day-to-day health. Creating  the care plan will involve a conversation with a health worker about the kind of support you might need and what's available.
ib.name: What a ‘care plan' is

ib.title: Find out what ‘training' means
ib.body: Skills and confidence training can help you live with and manage your condition more effectively. It's also a good way to meet people with similar conditions and questions.
ib.name: Find out what ‘training' means

ib.title: What kind of equipment?
ib.body: Depending on your mobility and/or the condition you have, there are devices and equipment available on the NHS to help you at home. These range from nebulisers (for people who have trouble breathing), telehealth monitoring equipment to take your blood pressure and send your readings to a clinician, to equipment such as stair rails to help prevent a fall.
ib.name: What kind of equipment?

ib.title: Find out about patient groups
ib.body: Meeting other people through a local or national support group can be a really good source of support and information. There are patient support networks for most long-term conditions. Your GP or Patient Advice and Liaison Services (PALS) is a good place to get more information on this kind of support.
ib.name: Find out about patient groups

ib.title: What ‘lifestyle changes' mean
ib.body: This means making changes in your everyday life like, such as giving up smoking, improving your diet or being more active.
ib.name: What ‘lifestyle changes' mean
